update.description:
I've updated the bitbucker_pullrequest tool to have the following syntax:
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests
Usage: bitbucket_pullrequests [options]
    -l, --list                       List open pull requests with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -s, --summary [id]               Summarize a pull request with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -c, --check [id]
    -f, --files [id]                 Show changed files in a pull request
    -h, --help                       Display this help message
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --list
  671    2beb52994344    de26348acac4    pullrequest_analysis
  634    a29eb4e20f24    de26348acac4    gui_interaction
  677    6df898525e5e    de26348acac4    osx_menubar
  680    96614934a358    de26348acac4    remove_internal_sdf
  561    a4569d964211    de26348acac4    pref_nate
  678    1b77d8f23a04    40d346454df0    gazebo_1.9
  673    d1f301d03fa1    de26348acac4    force_torque_test
  675    2b025a23303d    de26348acac4    wireless
  607    1e3e8158506a    de26348acac4    sensor_update_rate
  581    517ed0f039d5    7f3c8f2de150    spheres_links_question
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --summary 648
  648    8abe4e700683    47728f25191b    openal
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --files 648
cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder_TEST.cc
gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
…
test/regression/pr2.cc
test/regression/server_fixture.cc
test/regression/speed.cc
test/regression/speed_pr2.cc
~~~
I've also added an option to do a quick code check on the changed files with `-c` or `--check`. The only requirement for this option is that you invoke `bitbucket_pullrequests` from within a gazebo mercurial repository. It will tell you if you need to `hg pull`, and it won't touch the local files; it will `hg cat` to a temporary file and check that file.

I'm open to suggestions on the names for these tools.

pullrequest.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

content.raw:
For `--quick`, I was running cppcheck on both `.cc` and `.hh` files, while the regular code_check only does cppcheck on `.cc`. Those errors are indeed false positives.

In 5d77fb2, I change to do the quick cppcheck only on .cc files.
content.html:
For --quick, I was running cppcheck on both .cc and .hh files, while the regular code_check only does cppcheck on .cc. Those errors are indeed false positives.

In 5d77fb2, I change to do the quick cppcheck only on .cc files.

pullrequest.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

content.raw:
I think the quick code check will return false positives. Try running:

`./tools/bitbucket_pullrequests -c 561`

This will output:


```
#!c++

[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:41]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::id' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:43]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::duration' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:44]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::startTime' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:45]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::endTime' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:46]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::translated' is never used
```

However, I think that output is incorrect because those members are used in `Actor.cc`. Running the default `code_check.sh` works.
content.html:
I think the quick code check will return false positives. Try running:

./tools/bitbucket_pullrequests -c 561

This will output:

[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:41]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::id' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:43]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::duration' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:44]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::startTime' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:45]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::endTime' is never used
[gazebo/physics/Actor.hh:46]: (style) struct or union member 'TrajectoryInfo::translated' is never used

However, I think that output is incorrect because those members are used in Actor.cc. Running the default code_check.sh works.

The only requirement for this option is that you invoke `bitbucket_pullrequests` from within a gazebo mercurial repository. It will tell you if you need to `hg pull`, and it won't touch the local files; it will `hg cat` to a temporary file and check that file.

I'm open to suggestions on the names for these tools.
update.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests
Usage: bitbucket_pullrequests [options]

    -s, --summary [id]               Summarize a pull request with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -c, --check [id]
    -f, --files [id]                 Show changed files in a pull request

  675    2b025a23303d    de26348acac4    wireless
  607    1e3e8158506a    de26348acac4    sensor_update_rate

I've also added an option to do a quick code check on the changed files with `-c` or `--check`.

I'm open to suggestions on the names for these tools.

pull_request.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

update.description:
I've updated the bitbucker_pullrequest tool to have the following syntax:
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests
Usage: bitbucket_pullrequests [options]
    -l, --list                       List open pull requests with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -s, --summary [id]               Summarize a pull request with fields:
                                     [id] [source] [dest] [branch]
    -f, --files [id]                 Show changed files in a pull request
    -h, --help                       Display this help message
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --list
648	57b5158887e5	b2d2cf062c2b	openal
644	c2a7c28aed8f	b2d2cf062c2b	wireless
561	d98eb25697be	b2d2cf062c2b	pref_nate
634	fefc8632ba94	b2d2cf062c2b	gui_interaction
607	75ba4e5f7a23	b2d2cf062c2b	sensor_update_rate
581	517ed0f039d5	7f3c8f2de150	spheres_links_question
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --summary 648
648	57b5158887e5	b2d2cf062c2b	openal
~~~
~~~
$ bitbucket_pullrequests --files 648
cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.hh
gazebo/common/AudioDecoder_TEST.cc
gazebo/common/CMakeLists.txt
…
test/regression/pr2.cc
test/regression/server_fixture.cc
test/regression/speed.cc
test/regression/speed_pr2.cc
~~~
I've also added a tool called quick_check which uses the output of the pullrequest tool to determine the changed files in a pull request and run a subset of `cppcheck` and `cpplint` on those files. You just have to execute the code from within a gazebo mercurial repository that has been recently pulled. It doesn't touch any files in that repository, it `hg cat`'s to a temp file and does the code check on the temp file. It also tells you if there are new commits on the destination branch that haven't yet been merged to the source branch.
~~~
# quick check on all open pull requests
$ tools/bitbucket_pullrequests --list | bash tools/quick_check.bash
# quick check on pull request 648
$ tools/bitbucket_pullrequests -s 648 | bash tools/quick_check.bash
~~~
I'm open to suggestions on the names for these tools.
update.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

pull_request.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

pullrequest.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

content.raw:
If everything was in the ruby script then you could do:

`bitbucket_pullrequests --check` instead of `bitbucket_pullrequests --list | bash tools/quick_check.bash`

`bitbucket_pullrequests --check 648` instead of `bitbucket_pullrequests -s 648 | bash tools/quick_check.bash`
content.html:
If everything was in the ruby script then you could do:

bitbucket_pullrequests --check instead of bitbucket_pullrequests --list | bash tools/quick_check.bash

bitbucket_pullrequests --check 648 instead of bitbucket_pullrequests -s 648 | bash tools/quick_check.bash

update.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

pull_request.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

pullrequest.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

content.raw:
I split up the functionality because it was easier to write the REST client and json parsing in ruby, and it was easier to do the code check in bash.

Also, I've noticed that there can be a short delay between updating a pull request and seeing a response from the bitbucket command line tool. So it can be easier to manually paste in an updated changeset hash, ie:
~~~
echo 671	new_changeset_hash	0332ac8db9b7	pullrequest_analysis | bash tools/quick_check.bash
~~~
Or if there are internet connectivity issues or bitbucket is down, it's nice to be able to re-run the quick check without having to ping bitbucket.

We can make a 3rd command to save typing: `easy_quick_check -s 648`
~~~
#!/bin/bash
hg_root=`hg root`
$hg_root/tools/bitbucket_pullrequests $@ | bash $hg_root/tools/quick_check.bash
~~~
content.html:
I split up the functionality because it was easier to write the REST client and json parsing in ruby, and it was easier to do the code check in bash.

Also, I've noticed that there can be a short delay between updating a pull request and seeing a response from the bitbucket command line tool. So it can be easier to manually paste in an updated changeset hash, ie:

echo 671    new_changeset_hash  0332ac8db9b7    pullrequest_analysis | bash tools/quick_check.bash

Or if there are internet connectivity issues or bitbucket is down, it's nice to be able to re-run the quick check without having to ping bitbucket.

We can make a 3rd command to save typing: easy_quick_check -s 648

#!/bin/bash
hg_root=`hg root`
$hg_root/tools/bitbucket_pullrequests $@ | bash $hg_root/tools/quick_check.bash

pull_request.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

pullrequest.title: Update pull request tool and add quick_check script

content.raw: `quick_check.bash` seems like a tool that must be used with `bitbucket_pullrequests`. Would it be  possible to put the functionality of `quick_check.bash` into `bitbucket_pullrequests`? I could image running `bitbucket_pullrequests -s 648 -q` where `-q` is for a quick check.
content.html: quick_check.bash seems like a tool that must be used with bitbucket_pullrequests. Would it be possible to put the functionality of quick_check.bash into bitbucket_pullrequests? I could image running bitbucket_pullrequests -s 648 -q where -q is for a quick check.
